text.lat: 55.— In valle Nemeae leo ingens vivebat, et pecora hominesque quotidie interficiebat. Eurystheus, rex Tirynthis, Herculem ad se advocavit, eique dixit: ‘Curae tibi sit hunc leonem quam celerrime interficere.’ Statim proficiscitur Hercules. Clava sagittisque frustra usus, impetu facto, leonem manibus interfecit. Tum ad Eurystheum reversus est, mortuum leonem humeris impositum ferens.
text.eng: 55.— In the valley of Nemea lived a huge lion, and every day it killed cattle and people. Eurystheus, king of Tiryns, summoned Hercules to him and said: ‘Your task is to kill this lion as quickly as possible.’ Hercules sets out immediately. Having used club and arrows in vain, with a rush, he killed the lion with his hands. Then he returned to Eurystheus, carrying the dead lion on his shoulders.

text.lat: 56.— Olim in palude versabatur hydra. Haec novem capita habebat. Capita vero octo abscidit Hercules, nonum autem vulnerare non poterat; immortale enim erat. Abscisso quoque capite, bina statim enascebantur. His tandem igne consumptis, caput immortale sub saxo ingenti condidit Hercules. Belua ita devicta, sagittas venenato sanguine tinxit.
text.eng: 56.— Once in a swamp dwelt a hydra. It had nine heads. Hercules cut off eight of the heads, but he could not wound the ninth; for it was immortal. When any head was cut off, two new ones grew immediately. When Hercules finally destroyed these with fire, he buried the immortal head under a huge rock. With the monster thus conquered, he dipped his arrows in its poisonous blood.

text.lat: 57.— Exstitit in monte Erymantho aper mira magnitudine. Hunc capere iussus Hercules statim profectus est. Per nives diu insecutus aprum, tandem laqueis implicatum capere potuit, et ad Eurystheum rettulit.
text.eng: 57.— On Mount Erymanthus appeared a boar of remarkable size. Hercules was ordered to capture it and set out immediately. After pursuing the boar through the snow for a long time, he was finally able to capture it with nets and took it to Eurystheus.

text.lat: 58.— In Arcadia cervus erat aureis comibus, pedibus vero aeneis. Hunc sequi Hercules ab Eurystheo iussus erat. Frustra per totum annum cervum insecutus est; tandem sagitta vulneratum cepit.
text.eng: 58.— In Arcadia there was a stag with golden antlers and bronze hooves. Hercules was ordered by Eurystheus to pursue it. He pursued the stag the entire year in vain; finally, he captured it wounded with an arrow.

text.lat: 59.— Augeas, rex Elidis, tria millia boum habebat. Horum stabula per triginta annos non erant lota. Hercules Augean adiit, eique dixit: ‘Uno die haec stabula lavabo. Visne mihi, hoc facto, decimam boum partem dare?’ Respondit Augeas: ‘Dabo lubenter.’ Tum Hercules, converso per stabula amne, opus facillime intra unum diem peregit.
text.eng: 59.— Augeas, king of Elis, had three thousand cattle. Their stables had not been cleaned for thirty years. Hercules approached Augeas, and said: ‘I will clean these stables in one day. Will you give me a tenth of your cattle for this task?’ Augeas replied: ‘I will gladly give.’ Then Hercules, by diverting a river through the stables, completed the task very easily in one day.

text.lat: 60.— Vivebant olim in lacu ad Stymphalum in Arcadia aves pedibus et rostris et pennis aeneis: utebantur autem pennis suis pro sagittis, et carne hominum vescebantur. Aves adortus Hercules, sistro aeneo exterruit, tum fugere conantes sagittis interfecit.
text.eng: 60.— In a lake near Stymphalus in Arcadia once lived birds with bronze feet, beaks, and wings: they used their wings as arrows and fed on human flesh. Hercules attacked the birds, frightened them with a bronze rattle, and then killed them with arrows as they tried to flee.

text.lat: 61.— Bovem mirae magnitudinis et eximiae formae e mari emisit Poseidon. Hunc sacrificare Minos, Cretae rex, iussus erat; captus autem bovis specie, alium eius vice sacrificavit. Poseidon vero iratus, bovem in furorem egit. Tum bos per totam insulam magnam hominum stragem edebat, et opera agrestia corrumpebat. Hunc tandem captum Hercules ad Eurystheum portavit.
text.eng: 61.— A bull of extraordinary size and beauty was sent from the sea by Poseidon. Minos, king of Crete, was ordered to sacrifice it; however, captivated by the appearance of the bull, he sacrificed another in its place. Angry, Poseidon drove the bull mad. Then the bull wreaked havoc across the entire island, destroying crops and property. Hercules finally captured the bull and brought it to Eurystheus.

text.lat: 62.— Diomedes, Bistonum rex, equas carne hominum pascebat. Hercules vero equas clam abstulit, et ad mare duxit. Hic autem Bistones eum adorti sunt. Diu pugnatum est. Devictis tandem Bistonibus, Hercules regem interfecit, et corpus equabus dedit. Tum reversus est incolumis equas secum ducens. Hae vero mansuefactae sunt carne domini sui pastae.
text.eng: 62.— Diomedes, king of the Bistones, fed the mares with human flesh. Hercules secretly took the mares and led them to the sea. But here the Bistones attacked him. The fight lasted a long time. After finally defeating the Bistones, Hercules killed the king and gave his body to the mares. Then he returned unharmed, leading the mares. They became tame, fed on the flesh of their master.

text.lat: 63.— Hippolyte, Amazonum regina, zonam pulcherrimam habebat. Hac autem potiri volebat Admete, Eurysthei filia: itaque Hercules eam asportare iussus est. Tandem ad Amazonum terram pervenit. Ibi primum benigne excepit Hippolyte, zonamque promisit, sed coorta rixa, contra Herculem Amazones manus conseruerunt. His victis et occisa Hippolyte Hercules zona potitus est.
text.eng: 63.— Hippolyte, queen of the Amazons, possessed a very beautiful girdle. Admete, daughter of Eurystheus, wished to obtain this; hence Hercules was ordered to take it. Finally, he reached the land of the Amazons. There, at first, Hippolyte received him kindly and promised the girdle, but when a conflict arose, the Amazons fought against Hercules. When they were defeated and Hippolyte was killed, Hercules gained possession of the girdle.

text.lat: 64.— Geryones gigas triplici corpore in insula Erythia habitabat, multos boves habebat idem, a gigante Eurytione et a cane bicipite custoditos. Hercules his potiri volebat, itaque in Libyam et Hispaniam profectus est. Ibi ad utrumque latus maris columnas statuit: his igitur nomen Herculeis columnis datum est. Calore solis lacessitus in Helion tela coniecit: hic vero audaciam miratus, eum aurea cymba donavit: itaque Erythiam pervenire potuit. Interfecto Geryone cum Eurytione et cane, cum bobus reversus est.
text.eng: 64.— Geryones, a giant with a triple body, lived on the island of Erythia, and he had many oxen, guarded by the giant Eurytion and by a two-headed dog. Hercules wanted to gain possession of these, so he set out for Libya and Spain. There, he set up columns on either side of the sea: hence they were named the Pillars of Hercules. Stirred by the sun's heat, he hurled his weapons at Helios: the latter, impressed by his audacity, granted him a golden cup: thus he could reach Erythia. After killing Geryon along with Eurytion and the dog, he returned with the oxen.

text.lat: 65.— Mox opus difficilius Herculi imperatum est; mala scilicet Hesperidum iussus est asportare, non enim locum sciebat. In monte autem Atlante habitabant Hesperides. Ibi cum serpente ingenti mala aurea custodiebant. Locum tandem nactus Hercules, Atlanti dixit: ‘Visne mihi mala aurea auferre? Hoc te faciente caelum humeris impositum tui vice sustinebo.’ Cum malis reversus Atlas Herculi dixit: ‘Nunc tibi licet caelum humeris semper sustinere, ipse autem abibo.’ Tum Hercules per dolum onere humeris Atlantis iterum imposito, cum malis recessit.
text.eng: 65.— Soon a more difficult task was imposed on Hercules; namely, he was ordered to carry off the apples of the Hesperides, for he did not know the place. The Hesperides lived on Mount Atlas. There, with a huge serpent, they guarded the golden apples. Hercules finally found the location and said to Atlas: ‘Would you like to take the golden apples for me? While you do this, I will bear the heavens on my shoulders instead of you.’ Atlas returned with the apples and said to Hercules: ‘Now you may always carry the heavens on your shoulders, but I will go.’ Then Hercules, by a trick, having placed the burden on Atlas's shoulders again, left with the apples.

text.lat: 66.— His laboribus peractis, opus difficillimum Herculi imperatur. Erat in Tartaris canis triceps, nomine Cerberus. Hic aditum in Tartara custodiebat. Hunc in terram ferre iussus est. In Tartara profectus est cum Herma et Athena. Tum summo labore Cerberum manibus captum in terram secum portavit. His laboribus functus Hercules servitute ab Eurystheo liberatus est.
text.eng: 66.— With these labors completed, a most difficult task was laid upon Hercules. In Tartarus was a three-headed dog named Cerberus. This creature guarded the entrance to Tartarus. He was ordered to bring it to the earth. He went into Tartarus with Hermes and Athena. Then, with great effort, he captured Cerberus with his hands and carried it to the earth with him. With these labors finished, Hercules was freed from servitude to Eurystheus.
